ul:
PCI DSS Requirement 7.2.1 
    PCI DSS Requirement 7.2.3
li: Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on UNIX-type systems. Add the "umask 077" command to the login scripts for all users.

Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on Windows systems. Delete any excessive permissions by using the controls in the “Security” tab: right click on each drive, select "Properties", go to the "Security" tab, and delete all access permissions
 that are not explicitly authorized.

Enable the "deny-all" ACL default settings on other system-types. Most operating systems implement either the UNIX or the Windows type ACL system. Some network devices may have to be configured using a web interface. Follow vendor's instructions
 to configure ACL defaults on such devices.
p: Use a "deny-all" default setting for all access control systems.
Access control systems should have a "deny-all" default to ensure that all access is explicitly authorized.
Perform the following tasks to enable the "deny-all" default setting on access control systems:
Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on UNIX-type systems. Add the "umask 077" command to the login scripts for all users.

Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on Windows systems. Delete any excessive permissions by using the controls in the “Security” tab: right click on each drive, select "Properties", go to the "Security" tab, and delete all access permissions
 that are not explicitly authorized.

Enable the "deny-all" ACL default settings on other system-types. Most operating systems implement either the UNIX or the Windows type ACL system. Some network devices may have to be configured using a web interface. Follow vendor's instructions
 to configure ACL defaults on such devices.
ol:
Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on UNIX-type systems. Add the "umask 077" command to the login scripts for all users.
    
    
      
        Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on Windows systems. Delete any excessive permissions by using the controls in the “Security” tab: right click on each drive, select "Properties", go to the "Security" tab, and delete all access permissions
 that are not explicitly authorized.
    
    
      
        Enable the "deny-all" ACL default settings on other system-types. Most operating systems implement either the UNIX or the Windows type ACL system. Some network devices may have to be configured using a web interface. Follow vendor's instructions
 to configure ACL defaults on such devices.
strong: Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on UNIX-type systems.
Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on Windows systems.
Enable the "deny-all" ACL default settings on other system-types.

html:
Applies to

  • PCI DSS Requirement 7.2.1
  • PCI DSS Requirement 7.2.3

What to Do

Use a "deny-all" default setting for all access control systems.

Why

Access control systems should have a "deny-all" default to ensure that all access is explicitly authorized.

How

Perform the following tasks to enable the "deny-all" default setting on access control systems:

  1. Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on UNIX-type systems. Add the "umask 077" command to the login scripts for all users.

  2. Enable the "deny-all" ACL default setting on Windows systems. Delete any excessive permissions by using the controls in the “Security” tab: right click on each drive, select "Properties", go to the "Security" tab, and delete all access permissions that are not explicitly authorized.

  3. Enable the "deny-all" ACL default settings on other system-types. Most operating systems implement either the UNIX or the Windows type ACL system. Some network devices may have to be configured using a web interface. Follow vendor's instructions to configure ACL defaults on such devices.
